citations.narrative:
A current record of guinea pigs on hand was not available for review at time of this inspection. There were no inventory
records kept for the last few months indicating the number of adult guinea pigs and newborns present, except for a
calendar listing on Mondays of each week of new weanlings or guinea pigs that died. A total of 583 adult guinea pigs, 117
weanlings, and 113 newborns were counted during this inspection. Failure to maintain these records can make it difficult
to assess the health of the caviary by identifying animal losses by decreased number of guinea pigs born or raised.
Licensee must maintain records containing the required information for animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs
held, owned, acquired, or disposed of including births and deaths.

Lighting. The room housing 4 rows with 3 tiers high of adult guinea pigs and their offspring does not provide adequate
lighting to observe the animals in the middle and bottom tiers. Current inspection of the middle and bottom tiers can only
be accomplished by using a flashlight or other handheld light. Poor lighting in animal rooms does not allow for adequate
observation of animals and for the proper cleaning of enclosures. Indoor guinea pig facilities must be provided with good
quality lighting that is well distributed to permit routine observation, inspection, and cleaning during the entire working
period. Licensee must ensure that good quality lighting is provided that is well distributed in the animal room to inspect
guinea pigs in the middle and lower tiers in rows 1, 2, 3, and 4. Correct by March 1, 2024.

Space. There were 5 wire enclosures on a 5 tier rack housing 15 guinea pig weanlings in each pen. Wire enclosures with
the black pans measure 32 inches by 20 inches or 640 square inches of floor space. Guinea pigs weighing up to 350
grams required at least 60 square inches of floor space per animal. Can not house more than 10 weanling guinea pigs
weighing up to 350 grams in this size enclosure.
Inadequate space can cause stress and increase aggression in animals which can lead to bites, scratches, ear chewing,
and other injuries and health problems. Licensee must ensure that guinea pigs are provided with at least the required
minimum amount of floor space per animal to prevent overcrowding, stress, and aggression.

Primary enclosures for the adult guinea pigs and their offspring are not being cleaned and sanitized adequately or often
enough to remove excreta, dirty bedding, dirt, and debris from the sides and floors of enclosures. There were
accumulations of excreta, dirty bedding, dirt, and and debris on the sides and floors of enclosures in rows, 1, 2, 3, and 4
especially in the middle and lower tiers. The cleaning process (method and frequency) utilized is not effective in removing
this accumulation inside the enclosures.
Ineffective cleaning and sanitation can expose the animals to disease hazards and health problems. Correct by ensuring
that all primary enclosures are kept clean to prevent accumulations of excreta, dirty bedding, dirt and debris, and that
enclosures are sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by February 9, 2024.

There is not an adequate sanitation method being utilized to clean and disinfect the floors for the adult guinea pigs and
their offspring in rows, 1, 2, 3, and 4. The floors in these 4 rows are on a conveyor belt which is currently rotated once
each week. Licensee uses a gypsum powder to help control the ammonia levels, but there is no sanitation method
currently being used to clean excreta and organic matter that adheres to the belted flooring or a method used to properly
sanitize the floors. Ineffective cleaning and sanitation can expose the guinea pigs to disease hazards and health
problems. Licensee must use a method prescribed in this subsection to properly clean and sanitize the floors of animal
enclosures to maintain the health and welfare of the animals. Correct by February 14, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
A current record of guinea pigs on hand was not available for review at time of this inspection. There were no inventory 
records kept for the last few months indicating the number of adult guinea pigs and newborns present, except for a 
calendar listing on Mondays of each week of new weanlings or guinea pigs that died. A total of 583 adult guinea pigs, 117 
weanlings, and 113 newborns were counted during this inspection. Failure to maintain these records can make it difficult 
to assess the health of the caviary by identifying animal losses by decreased number of guinea pigs born or raised. 
Licensee must maintain records containing the required information for animals which disclose the number of guinea pigs 
held, owned, acquired, or disposed of including births and deaths. 
3.26(c) 
   
Facilities, indoor. 
Lighting. The room housing 4 rows with 3 tiers high of adult guinea pigs and their offspring does not provide adequate 
lighting to observe the animals in the middle and bottom tiers. Current inspection of the middle and bottom tiers can only 
be accomplished by using a flashlight or other handheld light. Poor lighting in animal rooms does not allow for adequate 
observation of animals and for the proper cleaning of enclosures. Indoor guinea pig facilities must be provided with good 
quality lighting that is well distributed to permit routine observation, inspection, and cleaning during the entire working 
period. Licensee must ensure that good quality lighting is provided that is well distributed in the animal room to inspect 
guinea pigs in the middle and lower tiers in rows 1, 2, 3, and 4. Correct by March 1, 2024. 
3.28(c)(1)(iii)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
Space. There were 5 wire enclosures on a 5 tier rack housing 15 guinea pig weanlings in each pen. Wire enclosures with 
the black pans measure 32 inches by 20 inches or 640 square inches of floor space. Guinea pigs weighing up to 350 
grams required at least 60 square inches of floor space per animal. Can not house more than 10 weanling guinea pigs 
weighing up to 350 grams in this size enclosure. 
 
Inadequate space can cause stress and increase aggression in animals which can lead to bites, scratches, ear chewing, 
and other injuries and health problems. Licensee must ensure that guinea pigs are provided with at least the required 
minimum amount of floor space per animal to prevent overcrowding, stress, and aggression.

3.31(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
Primary enclosures for the adult guinea pigs and their offspring are not being cleaned and sanitized adequately or often 
enough to remove excreta, dirty bedding, dirt, and debris from the sides and floors of enclosures. There were 
accumulations of excreta, dirty bedding, dirt, and and debris on the sides and floors of enclosures in rows, 1, 2, 3, and 4 
especially in the middle and lower tiers. The cleaning process (method and frequency) utilized is not effective in removing 
this accumulation inside the enclosures.  
 
Ineffective cleaning and sanitation can expose the animals to disease hazards and health problems. Correct by ensuring 
that all primary enclosures are kept clean to prevent accumulations of excreta, dirty bedding, dirt and debris, and that 
enclosures are sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. Correct by February 9, 2024. 
3.31(a)(4) 
   
Sanitation. 
There is not an adequate sanitation method being utilized to clean and disinfect the floors for the adult guinea pigs and 
their offspring in rows, 1, 2, 3, and 4. The floors in these 4 rows are on a conveyor belt which is currently rotated once 
each week. Licensee uses a gypsum powder to help control the ammonia levels, but there is no sanitation method 
currently being used to clean excreta and organic matter that adheres to the belted flooring or a method used to properly 
sanitize the floors. Ineffective cleaning and sanitation can expose the guinea pigs to disease hazards and health 
problems. Licensee must use a method prescribed in this subsection to properly clean and sanitize the floors of animal 
enclosures to maintain the health and welfare of the animals. Correct by February 14, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
